text: Introduction... In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. The Prohibition of Musical Instruments, or The Refutation by the Two Revelations (Quran and Sunnah) and the Sayings of Our Imams against Ibn Hazm and His Imitators Who Permit Musical Instruments and Singing, and against the Sufis Who Took It as an Act of Worship and Religion. Written by: Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: Introduction. Indeed, all praise is due to Allah, we praise Him, we seek His help, we ask for His forgiveness, and we seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our own selves and our bad deeds. Whomever Allah guides, there is none to misguide him, and whomever He leaves astray, there is none to guide him. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, having no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His slave and His Messenger. As for what follows: In the year 1373 AH, I came across an inquiry (Fatwa request) in the magazine 'Al-Ikhwan Al-Muslimun' (The Muslim Brotherhood) of Egypt, Issue 11, dated 29 Dhu al-Qi'dah of the mentioned year, about music and singing. Its text was: 'I am a young Muslim man who performs the rituals of religion and am very sincere, but there is something that dominates my soul, which is the love of music and singing, despite the fact that I memorize the Noble Quran. Is this hobby forbidden (Haram)?' The virtuous Professor Sheikh Muhammad Abu Zahra answered with the following text: 'Regarding singing, if it does not contain what arouses the sexual instinct, we do not find a reason to prohibit it. The Arabs used to recite Rajaz poetry, sing, and beat the daff (tambourine). It was reported in some narrations the invitation to beat the daff in marriage. It was said: The distinction between the lawful (Halal) and the prohibited (Haram) is the daff. And music is like that. We find that when Persian singing with melodies entered during the era of the Tabi'in (Successors), they were two groups:

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: A group inclined towards listening and did not find anything in it that touches religion, like Al-Hasan Al-Basri. And a group did not incline towards it and found it contrary to asceticism and piety, like Al-Sha'bi. In any case, it is agreed upon that as long as it does not arouse the sexual instinct and does not distract from the remembrance of Allah and from prayer, then there is nothing in it that touches religion.' I say: At that time, I wrote a response to this Fatwa due to its contradiction with the authentic Hadiths and the Madhhab of the majority of scholars, and I sent it to the magazine. But it seems that the suspension of the magazine during the era of Abdel Nasser and preventing it from issuing prevented its publication. In this Fatwa, despite its brevity, there are various errors and delusions that I did not imagine the Sheikh was too great to fall into. So I must clarify them with brevity as much as possible, except for what has a complete connection to the subject of the treatise. So I say: Songs and Music: 1- The reason for prohibiting singing is the authentic Hadiths established in the books of Sunnah, as will be explained, extracted and authenticated by scholars in this treatise. Does the Sheikh, who is among the senior scholars of Al-Azhar, ignore them or does he disregard them like some of his students as will come? Both are bitter. 2- The condition he legislated from himself: 'that it does not arouse the sexual instinct', and some of his students like Sheikh Al-Qaradawi and Al-Ghazali and others imitated him in it. The first one said, as will be quoted from him in this introduction, explicitly: 'And there is no harm if it is accompanied by non-arousing music',

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: meaning singing. So I say: This condition is theoretical, not practical, and cannot be regulated because what arouses the instinct differs according to temperaments: masculinity and femininity, old age and youth, heat and coldness, as is not hidden from the intelligent person. By Allah, I am extremely amazed at the succession of these Azhari Sheikhs on this theoretical condition. For despite their contradiction with authentic Hadiths and their opposition to the Madhhabs of the four Imams and the sayings of the Salaf, they fabricate reasons from themselves which none of the followed Imams said. Among its effects is permitting what is forbidden of singing and music according to them as well. Let us strike an example of that: One of them might have a wife, sons, and daughters, like Sheikh Al-Ghazali for example, who declares and perhaps boasts that he listens to Umm Kulthum and Muhammad Abdel Wahhab the musician and their likes, so his children see him, and perhaps even his students as he narrated in some of his writings. Can these people distinguish with their knowledge and adolescence between arousing music so they deafen their ears from it, or will they continue listening to it? By Allah, it is a Fiqh that does not issue except from a rigid hateful Zahiri (Literalist) or a person of desire who is not guided. This reminded me of the differentiation of the Hanafi Madhhab between wine (Khamr) made from grapes, which is all forbidden, no difference between little and much, and wine made from other than grapes like dates and the like, so only the large intoxicating amount is forbidden according to them (1). As for how to practically differentiate between the small non-intoxicating amount in it and the large intoxicating amount, and if
foot_note: 1. See the Fiqh of the Hadith of Al-Bukhari regarding the prohibition of wine and musical instruments in the first volume of Silsilat Al-Ahadith Al-Sahihah number 91.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: that is possible, then when? Before consuming it? Or after he gets drunk? This is among what they remained silent about and left the matter to the drinker, just as the referred Sheikhs did regarding the differentiation between forbidden arousing music and permissible non-arousing music. Does one say this who believes in the likes of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "And whoever roams around the sanctuary (Hima) is likely to fall into it." And his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Leave what makes you doubt for what does not make you doubt," to other texts of the Book and Sunnah upon which the rule of 'Sadd al-Dhari'ah' (Blocking the Means) was established, which is considered from the perfection of Sharia and which Sheikh Al-Qaradawi himself praised in the introduction of his book 'The Lawful and the Prohibited'? And Ibn al-Qayyim struck dozens of examples for it from the Book and Sunnah, so refer to it for it is important (1). Worse than this differentiation and that is what I had read in a bulletin of a well-known Islamic party that it is permissible for a man to kiss a foreign woman (Ajnabiyyah) when greeting her, not just shaking her hand but kissing her too. They said: But with a good intention and without desire. So all of these turned away from applying that great rule supported by dozens of proofs, along with their turning away from general proofs as is not hidden. Rather, they contradicted another example not mentioned by Ibn al-Qayyim which contains a refutation against them in the Sahih; these ones in their permission of kissing and shaking hands with foreign women, and those ones in listening to their songs like Al-Ghazali with Umm Kulthum. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, considered that a type of Zina (adultery), for he said: "Written upon the son of Adam is his share of Zina, he will inevitably catch that: The eyes, their Zina is looking.
foot_note: 1. 1 Ighathat Al-Lahfan min Masa'id Al-Shaytan 1/361-370 and what comes on p. 101. He will have good speech on this meaning and some examples on p. 153-156.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: The ears, their Zina is listening. The tongue, its Zina is speech. The hands, their Zina is grasping - and in a narration 'touching'. The leg, its Zina is stepping. [And the mouth, its Zina is kissing]. And the heart desires and wishes, and the private part confirms that or denies it." Narrated by Muslim and others (1). I say: Thus it becomes clear from what preceded the invalidity of the restriction of Sheikh Abu Zahra and those who imitated him regarding forbidden music and singing to what arouses the sexual instinct, and that the correct view is the prohibition of that absolutely due to the generality of the coming Hadiths and due to the rule of Blocking the Means. Similar to it in invalidity is what follows. 3- His saying: "And the Arabs used to recite Rajaz poetry, sing, and beat the daff." I say: This is false from several aspects which will be explained. It is clear that he means by "Arabs" the Salaf (Predecessors), and in that case, his expression about them with this term is a modern Jaahili nationalistic expression which is very strange to be issued from an Azhari Sheikh! So I say: The First Aspect: It is improvised speech with no head or tail (unfounded), not said by a scholar from
foot_note: 1. 1 The other narration is by Ibn Hibban and Ahmad, and the addition is by Abu Dawud and Ahmad. It is extracted in Al-Irwa 1868, Al-Sahihah 2804, Zilal Al-Jannah 193, and Sahih Abi Dawud 1868.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: before, so let it be struck against the wall. Second: That if he means by it their elite and their scholars as is assumed of him, then it is false, for what is transmitted from them contradicts that. And the Sheikh, may Allah forgive him, it is as if when he writes he does not have a scientific background, or at least he does not review a book from the books of Fiqh or a special research in it by one of the investigators of the Ummah like Ibn Taymiyyah and Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya, his case in that is like his student Al-Ghazali and his likes. Otherwise, where is he from the saying of Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him: Singing sprouts hypocrisy in the heart. It was narrated as Marfu' (attributed) to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, but the correct view is that it is Mawquf (stopped at the Companion) as Ibn al-Qayyim said in Ighathat Al-Lahfan 1/248, and therefore I extracted it in Al-Da'ifah 430. And from the saying of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him: The daff is Haram and musical instruments are Haram, and it will come on p. 92. And from what Abu Bakr Al-Khallal mentioned in the Book of Enjoining Good p. 27: And it is narrated from Al-Hasan who said: Daffs are not from the matter of the Muslims in anything, and the companions of Abdullah used to tear them apart. To other than that which is mentioned in its place, and see p. 102-103. Third: That those who used to beat the daff were women not men, and on the occasion of marriage, and regarding that are Hadiths I had mentioned in my book Adab Al-Zafaf p. 179-183, or on the occasion of Eid as in the Hadith of Aisha coming at the end of this treatise. Therefore Al-Halimi (1) said as in Shu'ab Al-Iman 4/283:
foot_note: 1. He is among the senior Shafi'i scholars and among the Muhadditheen. Died year 403 AH, biography in Al-Siyar and others.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: "And beating the daff is not lawful except for women because originally it is from their actions, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, cursed men who imitate women." 4- His saying: "It was reported in some narrations..." etc.: An imprecise expression, for he means by "narrations" (Athar) the Hadiths which I referred to just now. And worse than it is his saying following it: "It was said: The distinction between the lawful and the prohibited is the daff." For "It was said" (Qila) is from the passive forms of weakness (Tamridh) according to scholars, and it is only said regarding human speech, while this is a well-known Prophetic Hadith. If he intends by his mentioned saying to weaken it, he has erred twice, in narration and terminology. As for narration, the Hadith is Hasan (Good) as Al-Tirmidhi said, and Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi authenticated it, and it is extracted in the previously mentioned source and in Al-Irwa 7/50-51. As for terminology, it is only said regarding weak Hadith: "It was narrated" (Ruwiya) and not "It was said" (Qila). And there is another error which is his saying in the Hadith: "Farq" (Difference/Distinction), while according to them it is with the wording: "Fasl" (Separation/Decision). So contemplate how much ignorance of Hadith and its terminology is in the speech of this Azhari Sheikh. So it is no wonder that from his student Al-Ghazali comes what is more amazing and strange as will come. This matter indicates that Al-Azhar did not have care for teaching Hadith in terms of understanding (Dirayah) and narration (Riwayah). The greatest proof for that is that we do not see in this era a known famous Muhaddith with his works and writings who graduated from the noble Al-Azhar. And sufficient proof for what I say is this feeble speech from this senior Sheikh of theirs. And Allah is the One sought for help. 5- His saying: "And music is like that." I say: This is an analogy (Qiyas), and it indicates

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: that the Sheikh - like his student Al-Ghazali - rejects the Hadiths prohibiting musical instruments, including the Hadith of Al-Bukhari coming on p. 38. Or that he accepts them but is not good at analogy because there is no analogy in the presence of a text as the scholars of Usul say, and this is what I deem unlikely, how not when he has authored in Usul al-Fiqh? Or that he is from the Rationalists like his student, nothing stands before him, neither root nor branch, neither Hadith nor Fiqh, but rather desires running wild... Yet Al-Zirikli, may Allah have mercy on him, says about him in his book Al-A'lam: The greatest scholar of Islamic Sharia in his era. 6- He said: "A group inclined towards listening like Al-Hasan Al-Basri and a group did not incline towards it like Al-Sha'bi." Thus said the Sheikh, may Allah forgive him. He made forbidden singing a purely matter of taste like all permissible things such as food and drink; whoever wishes does it and whoever wishes leaves it. He was not satisfied with this, but attributed to the Salaf what contradicts what is established from them. Al-Hasan Al-Basri is innocent of what was attributed to him. Ibn Abi Al-Dunya narrated in Dhamm Al-Malahi (Condemnation of Instruments of Diversion) number 62 and 63 of my copy with two chains from him that he said: "Two cursed voices: A flute (Mizmar) at a grace and a wail at a calamity." This has been authenticated as Marfu' to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, as will come in the treatise, Allah willing: The second Hadith p. 51. As for Al-Sha'bi, Ibn Abi Al-Dunya also narrated number 55 with an authentic chain from him: That he disliked the wage of the female singer.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: And he narrated number 45 with an authentic chain from Al-Qasim bin Salman - Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy - from him that he said: "Cursed is the singer and the one sung to." And Ibn Nasr narrated in "Qadr Al-Salah" folio 151/2 with a good chain from him that he said: "Indeed singing sprouts hypocrisy in the heart just as water sprouts crops, and indeed Dhikr (Remembrance of Allah) sprouts faith in the heart just as water sprouts crops." So would Al-Sha'bi say the likes of this and that based on his personal inclination? O Allah, Your guidance. As for his saying: "In any case, it is agreed upon..", its invalidity has appeared from what preceded, so we will not prolong the speech by refuting it.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: On the first of the month of Sha'ban of the year 1375, some brothers showed me a collection of treatises by Ibn Hazm Al-Andalusi, edited by Dr. Ihsan Rashid Abbas. Among them was a treatise on distracting singing: Is it permissible or prohibited? In it, he argued for the permissibility of singing and musical instruments of various kinds. I imagined the extent of the bad effect this treatise would have on the hearts of its readers from the elite and students of knowledge, let alone the general public, due to two matters: First: Ibn Hazm's scientific fame in the Islamic world, even though he is of the Zahiri (Literalist) Madhhab and does not accept analogy (Qiyas), contrary to the four Imams and others. The Other: The dominance of desire over most people. If they see such an Imam arguing for the permissibility of what agrees with their desires, nothing will stop them after that from following their desires. Rather, they might find in what they hear from some Sheikhs justification for imitating him, like their saying: "Whoever imitates a scholar meets Allah safely." Some of them imagine it to be a Hadith, but it has no basis (1), even though Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, forbids imitation (Taqlid) and prohibits it severely. Added to that is the scarcity of sincere scholars who remind people of the correct ruling in this issue and the authentic Hadiths reported in it, and the abundance of what is written and broadcast contradicting them. So they imagine that what Ibn Hazm said is correct, especially as they read Fatwas by some contemporary scholars supporting his view, published in some circulated Islamic magazines

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: or broadcast on television in some Arab countries. Among that is another article published by the magazine 'Al-Ikhwan Al-Muslimun' also in Issue 5 under the title 'Islamic Music', in which it came: 'And the Symphony is: the highest reached by musical geniuses like Beethoven, Schubert, Mozart, and Tchaikovsky. It is an expression of emotions and feelings reflected from nature or humans. The largest number of skilled players with the latest various instruments are gathered for it so that the expression is as close to reality as possible. Egyptian Symphony bands have been formed comprising more than thirty players, assisted by the Young Men's Christian Association, and they played at the American University. How worthy we are of this, and how much we need a caller of a new type who will be an opening in the world of music and a global advancement for it. At that point, a unique color will emerge dominating the hearts of the world, which is Islamic Music instead of Oriental Music.' I say: This is one of the greatest proofs that the permissibility of musical instruments has spread among Muslims, even those among them who call for restoring the glory of Muslims and establishing the state of Islam like the Muslim Brotherhood for example. Were it not for that, their magazine would not have permitted publishing this article explicit in legitimizing what Allah forbade of music, and even calling to it. Not only this, but naming it Islamic Music on the pattern of Islamic Socialism and Islamic Democracy (1) and others, to which applies His saying, Blessed and Exalted:
foot_note: 1. 1 I say: Despite the contradiction between them, Sheikh Al-Ghazali praises it in his book "Islam the Slandered" p. 112, and resents Mu'awiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he was paving the way to destroy it. See the book of the virtuous brother Salman Al-Ouda "Quiet Dialogue" p. 29-30.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: {They are not but [mere] names you have named them - you and your forefathers - for which Allah has sent down no authority.} The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, pointed to something of that by his saying: "A group of my Ummah will indeed make wine lawful by a name they name it with," and in a narration: "they name it by other than its name." It is extracted in Al-Sahihah 90 and will come on p. 86. And I truly fear that the matter will increase in severity so people will forget this ruling, until if someone stands up to clarify it, that will be denounced against him and he will be attributed to extremism and reactionism, as came in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him: 'How will you be when a trial (Fitnah) covers you in which the adult grows old and the young grows up, and people take it as a Sunnah. If it is changed, they say: The Sunnah has been changed.' It was said: When is that, O Abu Abdur-Rahman? He said: "When your reciters increase, your jurists decrease, your leaders increase, your trustworthy ones decrease, the world is sought by the deeds of the Hereafter, [and knowledge is sought for other than religion]." Narrated by Al-Darimi 1/64, and Al-Hakim 4/514-515, with an authentic chain. And Al-Darimi also and Ibn Abd al-Barr in Jami' Bayan Al-Ilm wa Fadlihi 1/188, from another path from him with a good chain, and in it is the addition between the brackets. It is Mawquf (statement of Companion) with the ruling of Marfu' (attributed to Prophet) because it is from the matters of the Unseen that cannot be perceived by opinion, especially since everything in it of predictions has occurred. And Allah is the One sought for help.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: For that reason, I saw that it was necessary to author a treatise in which I clarify the ruling of Sharia on music, refute Ibn Hazm's saying of its permissibility, and clarify his delusions in weakening the authentic Hadiths prohibiting it, {so that those who were to live might live after clear evidence}. By that, the proof is established against the one who has no knowledge, and the guided one takes from it a proof to convince whoever wants guidance and fears his Lord. Damascus, 24 Sha'ban, year 1375 AH. Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani. That is what I had written more than forty years ago. Unfortunately, the matter has increased in severity as I had thought before. The affliction and fascination with songs and music has increased due to the availability of listening means like radios, recorders, television, and broadcasts, and the silence of many scholars from denouncing it, rather the declaration of its permissibility by some of them whom many think are senior scholars. Articles published in some newspapers and magazines permitting musical instruments, denying their prohibition, and weakening the Hadiths reported about them have multiplied and diversified, throwing against the wall the (opinions of) Huffaz who authenticated them and the Madhhabs of Imams who held their meanings, not addressing mentioning them so that the general readers imagine they have no existence. Or (these articles are) from obscure writers who are neither in the caravan nor in the troop (of no significance), as is said. Examples are many and very many. Suffice me now one example published in the Jordanian newspaper Al-Ribat, Issue 9-15, June 1993. It contained three articles permitting it by three of them. The most dangerous and worst of them is the article of the so-called Hassan Abdel Mannan, for he set himself up as an investigator to refute the Muhadditheen who authenticated the Hadith of Al-Bukhari coming regarding the prohibition of musical instruments through twisted ways and claiming false defects not

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: said even by Ibn Hazm, who is considered the Imam of these imitators in weakening, as will be explained, Allah willing. Some famous contemporary scholars have paved the way for them in denial and weakening, like Sheikh Yusuf Al-Qaradawi, imitating Sheikh Muhammad Abu Zahra - and his Fatwa regarding that has preceded, and perhaps he is one of his students who graduated from his school and suckled from his milk. He declared in his book 'The Lawful and the Prohibited' p. 291, 12th edition, under the title Singing and Music: 'And among the diversion that souls find rest in, hearts find delight in, and ears enjoy: Singing... And there is no harm if it is accompanied by non-arousing music.' He sought relief in that from the Madhhab of Ibn Hazm and his weakening of the prohibition Hadiths, so he quoted on p. 293 from him that he said: "Everything narrated regarding it is false and fabricated." The Sheikh, may Allah forgive us and him, ignored the successive refutations over the years against Ibn Hazm by the specialists in Hadith and its Huffaz and those more knowledgeable than him in it, like Ibn al-Salah, Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn Hajar, and others whose mention will come. He also ignored the apparent exaggeration in Ibn Hazm's judgment on the Hadiths as void and fabricated, for the existence of a defect in a Hadith does not necessitate judging it as fabricated, especially if it is in Sahih Al-Bukhari as is not hidden to beginners in this science. How then when there are other authentic Hadiths also as will come? If they were weak,

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: their aggregate would give the subject strength. So judging all of them as void and fabricated - undoubtedly - is apparently false. His friend, the famous writer Sheikh Muhammad Al-Ghazali the Egyptian, followed this pattern of ignoring the knowledge of specialists in his recent book: 'The Prophetic Sunnah Between the People of Fiqh and the People of Hadith'. In it appeared what used to appear from him sometimes in some of his books and articles scattered here and there of deviation from the Book and Sunnah and the Fiqh of the Imams as well, contrary to what he deludes his readers with, such as his saying in the introduction of his mentioned book p. 11: "I affirm first and last that I am with the Great Caravan of Islam, this caravan led by the Rightly Guided Caliphs, the Followed Imams, and the Trusted Scholars, generation after generation, and the later praying for the earlier." This is beautiful speech, but more beautiful is acting upon it and making it a method of life. But unfortunately, it is speech about which one says: Read and rejoice, test and grieve. For the man's doctrine has finally been revealed very clearly that he is not with the Great Caravan... etc., nor even with the Small one. Rather, he is with those anomalous Rationalists who have no doctrine except following what their minds adorn for them, so they take from every doctrine what pleases them of anomalies and oddities. Some of the Salaf said: 'Whoever carries the anomalous knowledge carries great evil' (1). Yet he
foot_note: 1. 1 Narrated by Abu Bakr Al-Khallal in 'Al-Amr bi Al-Ma'ruf' "p. 33, Al-Qassim" with an authentic chain from Ibrahim bin Adham, may Allah have mercy on him. Similar to it is the saying of Sulaiman Al-Taymi: "If you take the concession of every scholar, all evil will gather in you." Narrated by Ibn Abd al-Barr in 'Jami' Bayan Al-Ilm wa Fadlihi' 2/91-92.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: inserts himself into the group of Fuqaha who critique the Muhadditheen for an anomaly or a defect hidden from them. The truth is that the man has no knowledge of Hadith nor of the Fiqh derived from it. Rather, it is blind randomness contrary to what the scholars of Muslims from Muhadditheen and Fuqaha are upon in their principles and branches. If an authentic Hadith clashes with his opinion, he destroys it with a false claim from his many claims. For example, he says: 'So-and-so weakened it', while knowing that others more knowledgeable or numerous than him authenticated it, as is his stance on the Hadith of Al-Bukhari coming regarding musical instruments. Sometimes he rejects it claiming it is a solitary Hadith (Ahad), knowing also that the solitary report is proof in jurisprudential and practical matters by agreement. text: 1 - Chapter One: On mentioning the authentic Hadiths regarding the prohibition of singing and musical instruments. Know, my Muslim brother, that the Hadiths reported regarding that are very many. Their number exceeded ten according to Ibn Hazm and Ibn al-Qayyim. They are so numerous that their sum indicates to the one who examines them that their content, which their texts agreed upon - which is prohibition - is established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, with certainty, even if it is assumed that the chain of every single one of them is defective as Ibn Hazm claimed. This is by virtue of the rule agreed upon by Muhadditheen and scholars: That the weak Hadith is strengthened by the multiplicity of paths, as detailed in the science of Hadith terminology. With it, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and others strengthened the Hadith "The ears are part of the head" in his valuable book 'Al-Nukat ala Ibn al-Salah'. He cited it therein from four Companions and clarified their defects 1/410-415, then concluded by saying: "If the fair person looks at the sum of these paths, he will know that the Hadith has a basis and it is not something to be discarded. text: The First Hadith: From Abu Amir or Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari who said: "There will certainly be people from my Ummah who declare as lawful: illegal sexual intercourse (Al-Hir), silk, wine, and musical instruments (Al-Ma'azif). And people will certainly descend to the side of a mountain; their shepherd returns to them with their flock in the evening. A needy person comes to them for a need (1), but they say: 'Return to us tomorrow.' So Allah destroys them at night, brings down the mountain, and transforms others into monkeys and pigs until the Day of Judgment."

Also, he cited it in his Sahih Hadiths p. 50, 6-: "He forbade the earning of the Zammarah (prostitute/flute player?)" from the narration of Abu Ubaidah from Gharib Al-Hadith. He missed at its end: Hajjaj, one of its narrators, said: Al-Zammarah: The fornicatress (Zaniyah). I say: This prevents including it in the group of singing Hadiths, even if the word Zammarah linguistically allows it, for it is the feminine of Zammar, the player of Mizmar (flute). Although I notice a strong connection between the fornicatress and Zamr (flute playing), therefore it was said: Singing is the charm of Zina, but it is not necessary (to be the meaning here), and Allah knows best. The Hadith is in Al-Sahihah 3275. 1 Meaning a seeker of need as in the narration of Al-Isma'ili in his Mustakhraj.

text: Al-Bukhari suspended it (Mu'allaq) in his Sahih with the decisive form (Sighat al-Jazm) using it as proof, saying in the Book of Drinks 10/51/5590 - Fath: "And Hisham bin Ammar said: Sadaqah bin Khalid told us: Abdur-Rahman bin Yazid bin Jabir told us: Atiyah bin Qais Al-Kilabi told us: Abdur-Rahman bin Ghanm Al-Ash'ari told me, he said: Abu Amir or Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari told me - by Allah he did not lie to me - he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, saying:" so he mentioned it. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in his book Al-Istiqamah 1/294: "And regarding distracting instruments, what Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih as suspended (Ta'liq) but decisively asserted (Majzum bihi), entering into his condition (for authenticity), is authentic." I say: This type of suspension has the form of suspension, as Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in his extraction of this Hadith in Al-Mughni 'an Haml Al-Asfar 2/271. That is because most suspended Hadiths are disconnected between them (the author) and their suspended source, and they have many known forms. This is not one of them because Hisham bin Ammar is among the Sheikhs of Al-Bukhari whom he used as proof in his Sahih in more than one Hadith, as Al-Hafiz explained in his biography in the introduction of Al-Fath. Since Al-Bukhari is not known for Tadlis (concealment), his saying in this Hadith: "He said" (Qala) is in the ruling of his saying: "From" ('An) or: "He told me" (Haddathani) or: "He said to me" (Qala li), contrary to what the weakener of authentic Hadiths Ibn Abdel Mannan said as will come. The saying of Al-Iraqi mentioned resembles the saying of Ibn al-Salah in the Introduction to the Sciences of Hadith p. 72: "Its form is the form of disconnection, but its ruling is not its ruling (of disconnection), and it is not excluded from

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: the Authentic (Sahih) to the Weak (Da'if)." Then he refuted Ibn Hazm's finding fault with it due to disconnection. The completion of his speech will come, Allah willing, in Chapter Three. The intention is that the Hadith is not disconnected between Al-Bukhari and his Sheikh Hisham as Ibn Hazm claimed, and those who imitated him from the contemporaries, as will be explained in the mentioned chapter, Allah the Exalted willing. Even if it were assumed to be disconnected, it is a relative defect that is not permissible to cling to, because it has come connected (Mawsul) from paths of a group of trustworthy Huffaz who heard it from Hisham bin Ammar. So the one clinging to disconnection in this case is stubbornly denying in an obvious manner, like one who weakens a Hadith with an authentic chain by clinging to a weak chain for it. Let us mention then what I found of those trustworthy ones in the sources available to us, then refer for the others to the commentaries and others. First: Ibn Hibban said in his Sahih 8/265/6719 - Al-Ihsan: Al-Husain bin Abdullah Al-Qattan informed us, he said: Hisham bin Ammar told us with it up to his saying: "Musical instruments". This Al-Qattan is a trustworthy Hafiz, his biography is in Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala 14/287. Second: Al-Tabarani said in Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir 3/319/3417, and Da'laj in Musnad Al-Muqillin / The Selection from it, Al-Dhahabi's narration Folio 1-2/1, they said: Musa bin Sahl Al-Juni Al-Basri told us: Hisham bin Ammar told us with it like the narration of Al-Bukhari. From the path of Al-Tabarani, Al-Diya Al-Maqdisi narrated it in Muwafaqat Hisham bin Ammar Folio 37/1-2.

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: This Musa is a trustworthy Hafiz as well, biography in Al-Siyar 14/261. Muhammad bin Ismail bin Mahran Al-Isma'ili joined Da'laj with him; he is a trustworthy established Hafiz, and he is other than Al-Isma'ili the author of Al-Mustakhraj. Fourth: Al-Isma'ili said in Al-Mustakhraj 'ala Al-Sahih, and via his path Al-Bayhaqi in his Sunan 10/221: Al-Hasan bin Sufyan told us: Hisham bin Ammar told us with it. Al-Hasan bin Sufyan - who is Al-Khurasani Al-Naysaburi, an established Hafiz, among the Sheikhs of Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban and other Huffaz - his biography is in Al-Siyar 14/157-162 and in Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz. There are four others who heard it from Hisham, Al-Hafiz extracted them in Taghliq Al-Ta'liq 5/17-19 and Al-Dhahabi regarding some of them in Al-Siyar 21/157 and 23/7. Furthermore, Hisham was not alone in narrating it, neither he nor his Sheikh Sadaqah bin Khalid. Rather, they have been followed (corroborated). Abu Dawud said in his Sunan 4039: Abdul-Wahhab bin Najdah told us:

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: Bishr bin Bakr told us from Abdur-Rahman bin Yazid bin Jabir with his preceding chain from Abu Amir or Abu Malik as Marfu' (attributed to Prophet) with the wording: "There will certainly be people from my Ummah who declare as lawful Al-Khazz (type of silk) and silk - and he mentioned speech, he said -: Others of them will be transformed into monkeys and pigs until the Day of Judgment." I say: This is an authentic connected chain as Ibn al-Qayyim said in Al-Ighathah 1/260, following his Sheikh in Ibtal Al-Tahlil p. 27. But it does not contain the explicit mention of the witness (relevant point) from it, but rather he indicated it by his saying: "and he mentioned speech". It came explicitly mentioned in the narration of two other trustworthy Huffaz. One is Abdur-Rahman bin Ibrahim nicknamed 'Duhaym', he said: Bishr told us with the wording of Al-Bukhari mentioned previously: "They declare as lawful illegal sexual intercourse, silk, wine, and musical instruments." The Hadith. Abu Bakr Al-Isma'ili extracted it in Al-Mustakhraj 'ala Al-Sahih as in Al-Fath 10/56 and Al-Taghliq 5/19, and via Al-Isma'ili Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Sunan 3/272. The other is Isa bin Ahmad Al-Asqalani (1), he said: Bishr bin Bakr told us with it, except that he said: "Al-Khazz" with two dotted letters (Kh and Z), and the preponderant is with undotted letters (H and R - Al-Hir) as in the narration of Al-Bukhari and others. See Al-Fath 10/55. Ibn Asakir extracted it in Tarikh Dimashq 19/152, via the path of Al-Hafiz

text: "People from my Ummah will surely drink wine, naming it by other than its name. Musical instruments (Ma'azif) and female singers will be played over their heads. The most mentioned about him is Ibn Ma'in's saying: "I do not know him." Yet his student Uthman bin Sa'id Al-Darimi the Imam Al-Hafiz refuted him, saying in his History from Ibn Ma'in 101/287:

publisher: Al-Rayyan Foundation, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar Al-Siddiq, Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: "I said: So Hatim bin Huraith Al-Ta'i, how is he? He said: I do not know him. So Uthman said after it: He is a trustworthy (Thiqah) Syrian." I say: And it is established among scholars that he who knows is a proof against he who does not know. Ibn Adi said in Al-Kamil 2/439 about him: "And due to the scarcity of his Hadith, Yahya did not know him, and I hope there is no harm in him (La Ba'sa bihi)." From the completion of his deception and criticizing me is his saying after what was quoted from him: "And whoever improved his status (Hassana Amrahu) is not like one who spoke against him," referring to my declaring him trustworthy by the generality of my saying in the referred place in Al-Sahihah: "I said: And its men are trustworthy except Malik bin Abi Maryam." If you knew this, his mentioned saying reminded me of the famous proverb: "She threw her disease at me and slipped away." That is because the phrase: "improved his status" he means by it declaring trustworthy (Tawthiq), but he turned away

text: So what do the readers say regarding the stance of this man towards the sayings of our Imams and his prioritizing of his opinion based on ignorance and desire? We ask Allah for safety. Then I noticed two benefits in the extraction of this Hadith: The First: Al-Bukhari's saying in his narration of the Hadith of Ibn Salih from Mu'awiyah bin Salih: "Abdullah bin Salih told us" - and he is Abu Salih - and he said in another place - as preceded -: "Abu Salih said to me." This is decisive proof that there is no difference for Al-Bukhari between the two sayings: "He told us" and: "He said to me," and that his saying: "So-and-so said to me" is connected, and that it is not disconnected as claimed by the one ignorant of both science and language as preceded. The Other: Al-Bukhari's saying following the Hadith of Ibrahim - in which the narrator doubts the Companion of the Hadith by saying: Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari or Abu Amir: "This is only known from Abu Malik." I say: In it is a subtle indication that Malik bin Abi Maryam is known to him because he prioritized his narration which contains certainty that the Companion is Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari over the narration of his Sheikh Hisham bin Ammar which he extracted in his Sahih as preceded and the narration of Ibrahim mentioned just now, and in each of them is doubt in the name of the Companion. Were it not that Al-Bukhari sees that Malik bin Abi Maryam is trustworthy to him, he would not have prioritized his narration over the narrations of Hisham and Ibrahim. Perhaps this is what Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, noticed when he said regarding this Hadith of Malik: "Its chain is authentic." And Allah knows best.

text: The summary of speech on this First Hadith: Its pivot is on Abdur-Rahman bin Ghanm, who is trustworthy by agreement. Qais bin Atiyah the Trustworthy narrated from him, and the chain to him is authentic as preceded. And on Malik bin Abi Maryam and Ibrahim bin Abdul-Hamid who is trustworthy. All three mentioned musical instruments among the items decisively prohibited. So whoever insists after this on weakening the Hadith is arrogant and stubborn, upon whom applies the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "He will not enter Paradise who has in his heart a mustard seed's weight of arrogance." The Hadith, and in it: "Arrogance is rejecting the truth and looking down on people." Narrated by Muslim and others and it is extracted in Ghayat Al-Maram 98/114. The Second Hadith: From Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Two voices are cursed in this world and the Hereafter: A flute at a grace and a wail at a calamity." Al-Bazzar extracted it in his Musnad 1/377/795 - Kashf Al-Astar: Amr bin Ali told us: Abu Asim told us: Shabib bin Bishr Al-Bajali told us, he said: I heard Anas bin Malik say: so he mentioned it. And via the path of Abu Asim - and his name is Al-Dahhak bin Makhlad - Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i extracted it in Al-Ruba'iyyat 2/22/1 - Zahiriyah Manuscript, and Al-Diya Al-Maqdisi in Al-Ahadith Al-Mukhtarah 6/188/2200, 2201. Al-Tabarani narrated it in Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat (1 / 59 / 1060 by my numbering) and Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Shu'ab (5 / 377 - 378) via two paths from him, and Al-Bayhaqi strengthened it with them. He has two other paths in Dhamm Al-Malahi from him similarly (Folio 2 / 1 and 3 / 1) which I turned away from mentioning because they cannot be used as supporting evidence.

The Seventh Hadith: From Abu Umamah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'It is not lawful to sell singing girls, nor to buy them, nor to trade in them, and their price is unlawful.' - And he said: - 'This verse was only revealed regarding that: {And of the people is he who buys the amusement of speech} [Luqman: 6] until he finished the verse.' Then he followed it with: 'By the One Who sent me with the Truth, no man raises his voice in singing except that Allah Almighty sends at that moment two devils who climb onto his shoulders, then they do not cease striking his chest with their feet - and he pointed to his own chest - until he is the one who falls silent.'
Al-Tabarani narrated it in Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir (8 / No. 7749, 7805, 7825, 7855, 7861, and 7862) via two paths from Al-Qasim bin Abdul-Rahman from him. I say: I had cited it because of them in Al-Sahihah under No. 2922, then it became clear to me that one of them has severe weakness, so I turned away from strengthening it, except for the revelation of the verse, for it has witnessing narrations from more than one of the Companions, and mention of some of them will come in the eighth chapter, if Allah the Exalted wills (p. 142).

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: At the conclusion of these authentic Hadiths, of both types—authentic in themselves (Sahih li-Dhatihi) and authentic due to others (Sahih li-Ghayrihi)—it is necessary to mention an important issue to complete the benefit. I say: The scholars of Hadith—may Allah reward them with good—have proceeded upon very important scientific rules to preserve the heritage of the Prophet of the Ummah safe from addition and subtraction. Just as it is not permissible to attribute to him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) what he did not say, likewise it is not permissible to waste what he said or turn away from it. The truth is between this and that, as Allah the Exalted said: {And thus we have made you a just community}. There is no doubt that achieving moderation and the middle path between excess and negligence, and distinguishing the authentic from the weak, is not done through ignorance or desire, but through knowledge and following. That can only be through correct understanding (Fiqh) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and this understanding will not exist except by knowing what the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was upon in word, deed, and approval. Since the matter is so, no one can uphold it except one who is among the Jurists (Fuqaha) and is also knowledgeable in the science of Hadith and its principles, or at least is among their followers and upon their methodology. How excellent is he who said: 'The people of Hadith are the people of the Prophet, even if... they did not accompany his person, they accompanied his breaths.' They are the ones intended by the famous Hadith—despite the difference regarding its confirmation: 'This knowledge will be carried by the trustworthy of every generation; they will expel from it the distortion of the extremists, the plagiarism of the falsifiers, and the interpretation of the ignorant.' Indeed, and by the authentic Hadith: 'Verily, Allah does not take away knowledge by snatching it from the people, but He takes away knowledge by taking away the scholars, until when He leaves no scholar, the people take ignorant heads [as leaders]. They are asked and they give fatwas without knowledge, so they go astray and lead others astray.' The Two Sheikhs narrated it.

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: The Two Sheikhs [narrated it]. Therefore, Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in a chapter in Majmu' Al-Fatawa (18 / 51): 'Just as the one who does not know the evidences of rulings, his statement is not considered, likewise the one who does not know the methods of knowledge regarding the authenticity of Hadith, his statement is not considered. Rather, everyone who is not a scholar must follow the consensus of the people of knowledge.' I say: It is not hidden from the scholars that the basis of this consensus is the saying of the Exalted: {So ask the people of the message if you do not know}. So whoever is not knowledgeable in Hadith, distinguishing its authentic from its sickly, is not permitted to use it as proof except after asking those who know it. This is the text of the verse. So, a fortiori, it is not permissible for him to correct and weaken based on his ignorance, as Al-Ghazali and others among the pretenders to Fiqh (Mutafaqqihah) of the present age have done. The intent is that the likes of these should not be stubborn and weaken a type of Hadith which is known among the scholars as the 'Hasan' Hadith or the 'Sahih due to others' (Sahih li-Ghayrihi), like this sixth Hadith and others. For it is from their principles and rules to strengthen a weak Hadith by the multiplicity of paths, adopting from the likes of the saying of the Exalted regarding the testimony of a woman: {that if one of the two errs, then one of the two may remind the other}. Applying this rule is something only a few of those occupied with this...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: ...noble science can uphold, let alone others, because it requires extensive knowledge of Hadiths, their paths, their wordings, and the places of citation within them. Often, help from indexes of Hadith extremities does not assist in this; rather, it is the knowledge established in the soul of the one who has practiced it for a long time. The best one who discussed this rule and supported it with what Allah the Exalted gave him of knowledge is Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, in Majmu' Al-Fatawa (18 / 25 - 26). He said, as in my book Al-Radd Al-Mufhim (may Allah facilitate for me its drafting and publication): 'The weak [Hadith] according to them is of two types: Weak that is not prohibited to act upon, which resembles the Hasan in the terminology of Al-Tirmidhi. And weak whose weakness necessitates abandoning it, which is the flimsy (Wahi). A man may be weak according to them due to frequent mistakes in his Hadith, while correctness is predominant in him; [so they view his Hadith] for the sake of consideration (I'tibar) and support (I'tidad). For the multiplicity of paths and their abundance strengthen one another until knowledge may be obtained by them, even if the transmitters were sinners (Fujjar) or corrupt (Fussaq). So how about if they were just scholars but mistakes were frequent in their Hadith? This is like Abdullah bin Lahi'ah, for he was among the great scholars of the Muslims and was a judge in Egypt, narrating many Hadiths. But his books were burnt, so he began narrating from his memory, and much error occurred in his Hadith, even though correctness was predominant in his Hadith. Ahmad said: I may write the Hadith of a man for consideration, like Ibn Lahi'ah.'

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) clarified in another statement the reason for strengthening a weak Hadith through paths and the condition for that, and the obligation to hold to this rule. He said in Al-Fatawa (13 / 347): 'The Mursal narrations, if their paths are numerous and are free from collusion intentionally or [was] agreement without intent, are definitively authentic. For the report is either a truth matching the news or it is a lie whose author intended to lie or erred in it. So when it is free from intentional lying and error, it is truth without doubt. If the Hadith comes from two directions or directions—I say: like this Hadith of ours—and it is known that the informers did not collude to fabricate it, and it is known that such agreement does not occur coincidentally without intent, it is known that it is authentic. Like a person reporting an incident that occurred and mentioning the details of statements and actions in it, and another person comes who is known not to have colluded with the first, and he mentions what the first mentioned of details of statements and actions; it is known definitively that the incident is true in general. For if each of them had lied about it intentionally or by error, it would not customarily happen that each of them comes with those details which custom prevents two people agreeing upon without collusion from one of them with the other.' He said: 'By this method, the truthfulness of most of what has multiple different directions of this type of transmitted reports is known, even if one of them is not sufficient either due to its being Mursal or due to the weakness of its transmitter.' He said: 'This principle should be known, for it is a beneficial principle in being certain about many transmitted reports in Hadith, Tafsir, Maghazi (battles), and what is transmitted of people's sayings and actions...'

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: ...and other than that. For this reason, if a Hadith in which this occurs is narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from two aspects, with the knowledge that one did not take it from the other, it is asserted that it is truth, especially if it is known that their transmitters are not among those who intend to lie, but rather forgetfulness and error are feared from one of them.' This last section of his speech (may Allah have mercy on him) was mentioned similarly by Al-Hafiz Al-Ala'i in Jami' Al-Tahsil (p. 38), and he added: 'For it rises by the sum of them to the degree of Hasan, because what is feared of the narrators' poor memory is removed then, and each of them supports the other.' Similar to it is in the Introduction of Ibn Al-Salah and its summary by Ibn Kathir. Then Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him) said (p. 352): 'In such cases, benefit is derived from the narration of the unknown narrator (Majhul), the one with poor memory, the Mursal Hadith, and the like. For this reason, the people of knowledge used to write such Hadiths and say: It is suitable for witnessing narrations (Shawahid) and consideration (I'tibar), what others are not suitable for.' Then he mentioned the statement of Ahmad previously cited: 'I may write the Hadith of a man to consider it.' I say: From what preceded, a benefit from the benefits of the early Hafizs narrating Hadiths with chains containing weak ones, and then recording them nonetheless in their books, becomes clear to the student of knowledge. It is that they are a basic reference for consideration and tracking follow-ups and witnessing narrations that strengthen one another. Additionally, other valid educational and directive benefits may be derived from some of them...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: ...in meaning, even if that does not justify anyone asserting its attribution to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as is known among the people of knowledge, contrary to some people of desires, ancient and modern, as previously explained in the refutation of Sheikh Al-Ghazali in the introduction of this treatise. Therefore, Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd Al-Barr said in Al-Tamhid (1 / 58): 'The weak Hadith is not discarded'—meaning: not neglected—'even if it is not used as proof. And many a Hadith with a weak chain is correct in meaning.' The conclusion is that a Hadith weak in chain may be correct in meaning due to the agreement of its meaning with the texts of the Sharia, like the Hadith: 'Blessed is he whose own fault occupies him from the faults of people,' and many like it. However, that does not permit attributing it to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). It may also be correct in both meaning and structure due to its supporting evidences strengthening it, like this sixth Hadith and some before it. So let this be in your remembrance, and let not the loud speech of the ignorant and the rioting of the rioters turn you away from it. For we are in a time where its writers are many and its scholars are few. To Allah is the complaint, and there is no power nor strength except by Allah.

2 - Chapter Two: Explanation of Strange Vocabulary in the Hadith

After we finished listing the Hadiths prohibiting instruments of diversion (Tarab), which contain various terms—some general and inclusive of all types of instruments like 'Ma'azif', and some specific to some of them, being an individual type like 'Barabit' for example—and since other strange terms occurred in some verses and Hadiths, I saw that it is of complete benefit to explain them, clarify their meanings, and arrange them alphabetically while indicating their preceding locations.

1 – "Arikatihim" (Their couches) p. 64: In Al-Qamus: Arikah, like Safinah (in measure): A bed inside a Hajal (curtained canopy) covering it like a dome, or everything that is reclined upon such as a bed, platform, and mattress, or an upholstered bed.

2 – "Al-Awtaar" (The strings) p. 60 and 61: Plural of Watar. [Vocalized] with movement [Fatha on Ta]. The string of the bow and its suspender. Here it means: The strings that are tied and tightened on musical instruments like the Oud and the Qanun.

3 – "Al-Barabit" (The lutes) p. 65: Plural of Barbat: An instrument of diversion resembling the Oud. It is Persian Arabized. Its origin is 'Barbat'...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
...because the one playing it places it on his chest, and the name for chest is 'Bar'. [Al-Nihayah].

4 – "Batr al-Haqq" (Rejecting the truth) p. 51: It is rejecting it and denying it after its appearance.

5 - "Al-Hir" (Private parts/Fornication) p. 38: It is the vulva. Its origin is 'Hirh' with a Kasra on the Ha and Sukun on the Ra. Its plural is Ahrah. [Al-Nihayah].

6 - "Al-Khazz" (Silk/Silk blend) p. 42: Here it means what is woven from pure raw silk, which is silk.

7 - "Duwalan" (Circulation/Rotation) p. 66: Plural of Dulah with Damma. It is wealth that circulates, so it belongs to some people to the exclusion of others. [Al-Nihayah].

8 - "Rannat al-Shaitan" (The cry of Satan) p. 52: Here it means the sad sound.

9 - "Alam" (Mountain) p. 38: Meaning: Mountain.

10 - "Al-Ghubayra'" (Corn wine) p. 58 and 60...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
...an intoxicating drink made from corn (Dhurra).

11 - "Ghamt" al-Nas (Belittling people) p. 51: It is underestimating them, despising them, and defaming them without right. It is also 'Ghamas' as in Al-Nihayah.

12 - "Al-Qinnin" (Lute/Tunbur) p. 57, 58 and 60: It is the Tunbur in Abyssinian [language]. And 'Taqnin' is playing it. Ibn Al-A'rabi said this, as in Ighathat Al-Lahfan. In Al-Qamus: Al-Qinnin like 'Sikkin' (in measure): The Tunbur, and a game for the Romans used for gambling. I say: The first is definitely intended here because gambling is mentioned in the Hadith itself, which is Al-Maysir. It is among the stringed instruments of diversion, long-necked, having a semi-oval soundbox with two or three strings.

13 - "Al-Qiyan" (Singing girls) p. 63: Plural of Al-Qaynah, which is the songstress among slave girls. It is also pluralized as Qaynat.

14 - "Al-Qaynat" (Singing girls) p. 45, 65 and 66: See the previous entry.

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
15 - "Al-Kubah" (Drum/Nard) p. 56, 57, 58 and 60: It is the drum (Tabl), as explicitly interpreted in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas and Ibn Umar. Imam Ahmad asserted this, and Ibn Al-Qayyim relied on it in Al-Ighathah. He said: It is said: The Barbat (lute). See entry 3. Al-Khattabi said in Al-Ma'alim (5 / 268): 'Al-Kubah is interpreted as the drum (Tabl), and it is said: It is Nard (backgammon/dice). Included in its meaning is every string, Mizhar (lute), and similar instruments of diversion and singing.' There are other opinions regarding it which Sheikh Ahmad Shakir (may Allah have mercy on him) quoted in the commentary on Al-Musnad (10 / 76), then he said: 'Better than all of this and more comprehensive is the statement of Ahmad in Kitab Al-Ashribah [84 / 214]: He means by Al-Kubah everything that is beaten upon.'

16 - "Al-Mazameer" (Flutes/Wind instruments) p. 51, 52 and 61: Plural of Mizmar: An instrument of reed—or metal—ending its tube with a small horn (bell). Thus in Al-Mu'jam Al-Wasit.

17 - "Al-Mizr" (Beer/Nabidh) p. 58: With a Kasra on the Mim: Nabidh (fermented drink) made from corn, and it is said: from barley or wheat. [Al-Nihayah].

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text: 18 - "Al-Ma'azif" (Musical instruments) p. 38, 45 and 51: They are Duff (tambourines) and others which are beaten upon, as in Al-Nihayah. In Al-Qamus: They are instruments of diversion like the Oud and Tunbur. Singular is 'Azf' or 'Mi'zaf' like 'Minbar' and 'Miknasah'. The 'Azif' is the one playing them and the singer. Therefore, Ibn Al-Qayyim said in Al-Ighathah: 'They are all instruments of amusement; there is no disagreement among the philologists regarding that.' Clearer than that is the statement of Al-Dhahabi in Al-Siyar (21 / 158): 'Ma'azif: A name for all instruments of diversion which are played, such as the flute (Mizmar), Tunbur, Reed pipe (Shabbabah), and Cymbals (Sunuj).' Similar to it is in his book Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz (2 / 1337).

3 - Chapter Three: The Refutation of Ibn Hazm and Others Who Found Fault with Some of the Preceding Hadiths

I say: I have previously refuted Ibn Hazm and others among those who attack authentic Hadiths in the introduction and during the referencing of the six authentic Hadiths mentioned above. What I wish to clarify now is that the prohibiting Hadiths, in relation to Ibn Hazm and our view of them, are divided into three categories:
First: That which he weakened, and he is mistaken.
Second: That which he did not come across, or he came across some of its paths but not others. Had he come across them and had they been established for him, he would have adopted them, so he is excused—unlike his imitators (Muqallidin)—especially since he commented on what he weakened by saying, swearing without breaking his oath if Allah wills (9 / 59): 'By Allah, if all of it or one of it were attributed (Musnad) via the path of trustworthy narrators to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), we would not hesitate to adopt it.' This is what we think of him, and Allah is his Reckoner. As for those who imitate him after the proof has been established against them and the path has become clear to them, they have no excuse and no dignity. Rather, their likeness is that of people in Jahiliyyah (pre-Islamic ignorance) who used to worship jinn; these [people] became Muslim, while those [others] continued in their worship and error, as Allah the Exalted said: {Those whom they invoke seek means of access to their Lord...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
...[striving as to] which of them would be nearest, and they hope for His mercy and fear His punishment. Indeed, the punishment of your Lord is ever feared.} [Al-Isra: 57].

Third: That which he weakened, and no objection appeared to us regarding it, so we have no concern with it.
My refutation of him will therefore be in the first and second categories. I say, and by Allah is success:

The First Category:
Ibn Hazm criticized two Hadiths out of the six: The first and the third.
As for the first Hadith: I mentioned for it previously two paths to Abdul-Rahman bin Ghanm from Abu Amir or Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari. The first: Via the path of Al-Bukhari: Hisham bin Ammar said: Sadaqah bin Khalid narrated to us... with his chain from Abdul-Rahman bin Ghanm Al-Ash'ari: Abu Amir or Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari narrated to me—and by Allah he did not lie to me—he heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Ibn Hazm found two defects in it: Disconnection (Inqita') between Al-Bukhari and Hisham, and the other is the anonymity (Jahalah) of the Companion Al-Ash'ari. He said in Al-Muhalla (9 / 59), which is the last of the Hadiths of the chapter according to him: 'This is disconnected; it is not connected between Al-Bukhari and Sadaqah bin Khalid, and nothing is authentic in this chapter ever, and everything in it is fabricated (Mawdu').' Thus he said. It is not hidden from students of knowledge, let alone scholars, the strictness and exaggeration contained therein. For disconnection—if true—does not necessitate judging the text as fabricated, especially since it came connected via another path according to him, and a third according to us, as preceded and will come. Yet despite all this, Al-Qaradawi and Al-Ghazali—and those who followed them—closed their eyes to all of that...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
...and imitated him as previously mentioned. Was that out of ignorance on their part or out of desire? We seek refuge in Allah the Exalted. His [Ibn Hazm's] saying: '...and Sadaqah bin Khalid' is an error, perhaps a slip of the pen from him; the correct reading is '...and Hisham bin Ammar' as previously mentioned in the refutation of Al-Ghazali (28 - 29). He said in his treatise (p. 97): 'Al-Bukhari did not cite it as attributed (Musnad); rather he said in it: Hisham bin Ammar said. Then it goes to Abu Amir or Abu Malik, and this Abu Amir is not known!'
As for the answer regarding the disconnection, its explanation has preceded in detail on more than one occasion; see for example p. 28 and 39 - 40. However, to complete the benefit, I will quote here some of what the Hafizs and critics said refuting Ibn Hazm's mentioned defect finding, so that the readers may increase in knowledge of the extent of the misguidance of those deviating from the path of the believers due to their persistence in imitating him blindly coupled with following desire. I say:

1 - The erudite scholar Ibn Al-Qayyim said in Ighathat Al-Lahfan (1 / 259 - 260) and in Tahdhib Al-Sunan (5 / 271 - 272) with some merging and summarization: 'No one has done what Ibn Hazm did in attacking the authenticity of this Hadith to support his false doctrine regarding the permissibility of instruments of diversion. He claimed it is disconnected because Al-Bukhari did not connect his chain to it. This attack is invalid from several aspects:
One: That Al-Bukhari met Hisham bin Ammar and heard from him. So if he says...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
"...'Hisham said,' it is of the status of his saying: 'From (An) Hisham' by agreement.
Two: That even if he did not hear from him, he would not permit affirming it (Jazm) from him unless it was authentic from him that he narrated it. This often happens due to the multitude of those who narrated it from him from that Sheikh and its fame. For Al-Bukhari is the furthest of Allah's creation from Tadlis (concealing defects in the chain).
Three: That he included it in his book named 'Al-Sahih' using it as proof. Were it not authentic according to him, he would not have done that. So the Hadith is authentic without doubt.
Four: That he suspended it with the format of certainty (Sighat al-Jazm) without the format of weakness (Sighat al-Tamrid). For if he hesitates about a Hadith or it is not upon his condition, he says: 'It is narrated (Yurwa) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)' and 'It is mentioned (Yudhkar) from him' and the like. But if he says: 'The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said' and 'So-and-so said', then he has affirmed and cut definitively its attribution to him. Here he affirmed the attribution of the Hadith to Hisham, so it is authentic according to him.
Five: That even if we turned away from all this completely, the Hadith is authentic and connected according to others.' Then he mentioned the Hadith of Bishr bin Bakr mentioned previously (p. 42) from the narration of Al-Isma'ili, and it contains the word 'Ma'azif' (musical instruments) which Hassan, the weakened one, denied existing!.

2 - Ibn Al-Salah mentioned something similar before in Introduction to the Sciences of Hadith (p. 72 - 73) and said: 'The Hadith is authentic, known to be connected upon the condition of the Sahih.'

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
3 - Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar followed him in Al-Fath (10 / 52 - 53), clarifying the reason that leads Al-Bukhari to such suspension (Ta'liq), then he said: 'It is established among the Hafizs that whatever Al-Bukhari brings of suspended narrations (Ta'aliq) entirely in the format of certainty (Jazm) is authentic up to the one he suspended it from, even if he was not among his Sheikhs. However, if the suspended Hadith is found from the narration of some Hafizs connected to the one he suspended it from with the condition of authenticity, the ambiguity is removed. For this reason, I took care of this type in the beginning of the matter and authored the book Taghliq Al-Ta'liq. Our Sheikh mentioned in the commentary on Al-Tirmidhi and in his speech on the sciences of Hadith that the Hadith of Hisham bin Ammar came from him connected in the Mustakhraj of Al-Isma'ili.' He said: '...' Then he cited its chain and followed it with the chain of Abu Dawood. Their mention has preceded along with other narrations from a group of trustworthy narrators who said: 'Hisham bin Ammar narrated to us...' So see page 40 - 41.

Then I came across a Hadith rule by Ibn Hazm where he meets with what preceded from the Imams of Hadith, that the mentioned suspension of Al-Bukhari is in the ruling of a connected chain between Al-Bukhari and his Sheikh Hisham bin Ammar. He said in Usul Al-Ahkam (1 / 141): 'As for the Mudallis (one who conceals chain defects), he is divided into two types: One: A just Hafiz who perhaps narrates his Hadith as Mursal, and perhaps connects it, and perhaps narrates it by way of negotiation, fatwa, or debate, so he does not mention a chain for it. And perhaps he limits himself to mentioning some of its narrators without others. This does not harm the rest of his narrations at all, because this is not a wound (Jarhah)...

publisher: Mu'assasat al-Rayyan, Beirut, Lebanon / Dar al-Siddiq, Al-Jubail, Saudi Arabia
text:
...nor negligence. However, we leave from his Hadith what we know for certain he sent as Mursal and what we know he dropped some of who were in its chain, and we take from his Hadith what we are not certain about anything of that. Whether he said: "So-and-so informed us" or said: "From so-and-so" or said: "So-and-so from so-and-so", all of that is obligatory to accept unless it is ascertained that he presented a specific Hadith in a non-attributed manner. If we ascertain that, we leave that Hadith alone only, and we take the rest of his narrations.'

I say: This is a text from him regarding what was mentioned, explicit in obligating the acceptance of Al-Bukhari's saying: 'Hisham said,' and that it is like his saying: 'Hisham informed us.' Thus, his declaring it defective due to disconnection falls, and consequently it is proven that his imitators {follow not except assumption and what [their] souls desire} [Al-Najm: 23]. And Allah is the One sought for help.

With this, the answer to the first defect, which is the disconnection alleged by Ibn Hazm and his imitators, ends, and it becomes clearly evident that it is a mirage.

There remains the answer to the other defect, which is the doubt in the name of the Companion. It is a doubt even weaker according to scholars. The Hafiz said in Al-Fath (10 / 24): 'Doubt in the name of the Companion does not harm. Ibn Hazm found defect with it, and it is rejected.'
I say: That is because the narrator from him declaring hearing from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is a trustworthy one from the senior Successors (Tabi'in); indeed, it was said he had Companionship. So he is among those knowledgeable about the Companionship of the one speaking to him from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), especially since he emphasized that by saying: 'By Allah, he did not lie to me.' So his doubt and hesitation do not harm us thereafter as long as he informed us of his [the narrator's] Companionship. Supporting this is the statement of Ibn Hazm in the chapter on the attribute of the one whose transfer of reports is obligated to accept from his book Al-Ihkam fi Usul Al-Ahkam...

text: 4 - Chapter Four: On the Indication of the Hadiths regarding the Prohibition of Instruments of Diversion in All Their Forms. Know, my Muslim brother, that the preceding Hadiths are explicitly indicative of the prohibition of musical instruments in all their forms and types, textually specifying some like the flute (Mizmar), drum (Tabl), and lute (Barbat), and appending others to them. This is for two reasons: First: The inclusion of the word 'Ma'azif' for them in the language, as preceded in Chapter Two and as will also come from Ibn al-Qayyim. Second: They are like them in meaning in terms of entertainment (Tatrib) and distraction (Ilha'). This is supported by the saying of Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "The daff (tambourine) is Haram, musical instruments (Ma'azif) are Haram, the drum (Kubah) is Haram, and the flute (Mizmar) is Haram." Al-Bayhaqi extracted it 10/222, from the path of Abdul-Karim Al-Jazari from Abu Hashim Al-Kufi from him. I say: This is an authentic chain if Abu Hashim Al-Kufi is Abu Hashim Al-Sinjari named Sa'd, for he is Jazari like Abdul-Karim, and they mentioned that he narrated from him. However, I did not see anyone mention that he is Kufi. In Thiqat Ibn Hibban 4/296, it is mentioned that he resided in Damascus. And Allah knows best. However, the First Hadith "They declare as lawful illegal sexual intercourse, silk, wine, and musical instruments.."

text: is in need of some explanation, so I say: First: His saying: "Yastahillun" (They declare as lawful), for it is clear in indication that the four mentioned things are not lawful legislatively, and among them are musical instruments. It has come in language books, including Al-Mu'jam Al-Wasit: "Istahalla al-shay'" means he counted it lawful. Therefore, the scholar Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in Al-Mirqat 5/106: "And the meaning is: They count these things as lawful by bringing forth doubts and weak evidences. Among them is what some of our scholars - meaning the Hanafis - mentioned that silk is only forbidden if it is touching the body, but if it is worn over clothes, there is no harm in it. This is a restriction without textual or rational evidence, and due to the unrestrictedness of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Whoever wears silk in this world will not wear it in the Hereafter' (1). Likewise, for some scholars regarding musical instruments there are attachments whose explanation would be lengthy. And this Hadith is supported by His saying, Exalted is He: {And of the people is he who buys the amusement of speech to mislead [others] from the way of Allah without knowledge}." I say: Similar to what he mentioned about the Hanafis is their differentiation between wine made from grapes, so little and much of it is forbidden, and wine made from dates and others, so only the large intoxicating amount is forbidden. This is a detestable literalism. Similar to it is the differentiation between music arousing to sex, so it is forbidden, and other music, so it is lawful, as preceded in the Introduction in the refutation of Abu Zahra

text: 5 - Chapter Five: The Madhhabs of Scholars on the Prohibition of Instruments of Diversion. After we established previously the authenticity of the Hadiths prohibiting instruments and clarified their indication of prohibition, it is appropriate for us to follow that by clarifying the stance of scholars and Fuqaha regarding adopting and acting upon them. So that the student be knowledgeable from the Fiqh perspective as well, and thereby increase in knowledge of Al-Ghazali's deviation in his book 'The Prophetic Sunnah Between the People of Fiqh and the People of Hadith' - and those who followed his path - from Fiqh and its scholars just as he deviated from Sunnah and its scholars. For he described them all - with extreme ignorance - as 'Preachers' (Wu'az) p. 74, for their prohibiting of singing. Imam Al-Shawkani said in Nail Al-Awtar 8/83, summarized: "There has been disagreement regarding singing with an instrument of diversion and without it. The majority went to prohibition, using as evidence what preceded - meaning the Hadiths. And the people of Medina and those who agreed with them from the Zahiri scholars and Sufis went to granting concession (Rukhsa) in listening (Sama'), even with the oud (lute) and reed flute (Yara')." Then he quoted from some of them that he related sayings from some of the Salaf regarding permissibility, and expanded on that an expansion of no benefit, because they are sayings mostly suspended (Mu'allaqah) with no head or tail (unfounded). And regarding some of them, the opposite has been authentically reported. And some are doubtful in their wording as will come

But before that, I want to draw attention to two matters: First: That the intended meaning by 'The Majority' here is the four Imams following the Salaf, as detailed by the scholar Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya in Ighathat Al-Lahfan 1/226-230. Therefore, when Ibn Al-Mutahhar Al-Shi'i attributed to Ahlus-Sunnah the permissibility of instruments of diversion and singing, Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah belied him in his refutation of him in Minhaj Al-Sunnah, saying 3/439: "This is from the lies against the four Imams, for they agree on the prohibition of musical instruments which are instruments of diversion like the oud and the like. If someone destroys them, he is not liable for the value of the destroyed item according to them; rather, taking them as property is prohibited according to them." The other matter: Al-Shawkani's attributing the concession to the people of Medina gives the impression by its absoluteness that Malik is among them, and it is not so, even if he was preceded in it, like the saying of Al-Dhahabi in the biography of Yusuf bin Ya'qub bin Abi Salamah Al-Majishun: "I say: The people of Medina take concession in singing and they are known for leniency in it." And he mentioned therein: That his slave girls in his house used to play the musical instrument (Mi'zaf). So I say: Imam Malik is certainly not among them. Rather, he and others from the scholars of Medina denounced it on them. Abu Bakr Al-Khallal narrated in Al-Amr bi Al-Ma'ruf p. 32, and Ibn Al-Jawzi in Talbis Iblis p. 244, with an authentic chain from Ishaq bin Isa Al-Tabba' - trustworthy from the men of Muslim - who said:

text: "I asked Malik bin Anas about what the people of Medina take concession in regarding singing? He said: Only the immoral ones (Fussaq) among us do it." Then Al-Khallal narrated with his authentic chain also from Ibrahim bin Al-Mundhir - a Medinan trustworthy scholar, among the Sheikhs of Al-Bukhari - and he was asked, it was said to him: "You take concession [in] singing?" As for the sayings Al-Shawkani quoted which were referred to previously and we promised to speak about, the answer is from two aspects: First: That even if their attribution to their speaker is authentic, and among them are the Kufan and the Medinan and others, there is no proof in them for contradicting the authentic explicit Hadiths presented previously. Abu Husain said: That a man broke a Tanbur (mandolin-like instrument) of another man, so he brought the dispute to Shuraih, and he did not make him liable for anything. Abu Dawud narrated similar to it from him in his Masa'il

I incline towards the saying of the first for two reasons:

text: One of them: He had longer companionship with Ibn Sirin and is more trustworthy than him regarding all his Sheikhs. Therefore, we found scholars differentiating between them and it regarding destroying them. Al-Khallal narrated p. 28 from Ja'far - he is Ibn Muhammad - who said: I asked Abdullah about breaking the Tanbur, Oud, and Tabl (drum)? He said: It has been narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the wedding. He refers to the Hadith "The distinction between the lawful and the prohibited..." It has passed in the Introduction p. 10-11, with the errors of Sheikh Abu Zahra about it. It is as if Imam Ahmad hints by that that the Hadith necessitates not interfering with the Daff by destruction because its use was permitted in marriage.
