text: 6 - Chapter Six: Doubts of the Permitters and Their Answer. After we invalidated with what we presented of authentic Hadiths and preponderant Madhhabs of Imams the adherence of Ibn Hazm and his imitators to the Default Principle (Al-Asl) which is Permissibility, and his claim that no text came prohibiting any of the instruments, it is from the completion of the research and benefit that we mention what he supported his alleged principle with, then the refutation of it with what scholars answered. So I say: Ibn Hazm held onto two Hadiths in his treatise 98-99, and in Al-Muhalla 9/61-62: One of them: From Aisha. The other: From Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both. 1 - As for the Hadith of Aisha, he cited it from the narration of Muslim alone. Al-Bukhari and others also narrated it, and it is extracted in Ghayat Al-Maram 399. I had included it in my book Mukhtasar Sahih Al-Bukhari number 508, with its context at the beginning of the Book of Eidain, adding to it all additions and benefits scattered in various subjects and chapters of Sahih Al-Bukhari from her Hadith. Therefore, I will quote its context from it deleting volume and page numbers of the additions. She said, may Allah be pleased with her: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered upon me while I had two girls [from the girls of the Ansar] - and in a narration: two singing girls (Qainatan) - [in the days of Mina beating the daff and hitting] singing with singing - and in a narration: with what was said - and in another: what the Ansar hurled at each other on the day of Bu'ath. [And they were not

text: singers]. He lay down on the bed and turned his face away. Abu Bakr entered [while the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was covered with his garment], so he scolded me - and in a narration: scolded them - and said: A flute of - and in a narration: flute of Satan in the presence of - and in a narration: Flutes of Satan in the house of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him [twice?]. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, turned to him - and in a narration: So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, uncovered his face - and said: "Leave them" [O Abu Bakr [for] "Indeed every people has an Eid and this is our Eid"]. When he became inattentive, I signaled to them and they went out. I say: So Ibn Hazm argued for the permissibility of singing with the daff. He said commenting on her saying: 'And they were not singers': "We said: Yes, but she said: they were singing. So singing from them is established. And her saying: 'they were not singers' means: they were not proficient. All this is no proof. The proof is only in his denial, peace and blessings be upon him, against Abu Bakr's saying: 'Is it the flute of Satan in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him?' So it is correct that it is absolutely permissible with no dislike, and whoever denied it has erred without doubt." In answer to him I say, and I seek Allah's help: It is very clear to every onlooker in this Hadith that it does not contain the absolute permissibility he claimed. How so, when it would include with the young girls - adult women, and even men too, and include all instruments of diversion and all days of the year - and this is a very clear error involving loading the Hadith with what it does not bear. Its cause is another error clearer than it which he fell

text: into, which is his saying: "The proof is only in his denial, peace and blessings be upon him, against Abu Bakr's saying: 'Is it the flute of Satan in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him?'" I say: There is nothing in the Hadith of this denial, even by way of indication. Rather, it contains his denial, peace and blessings be upon him, of Abu Bakr's denial against the two girls, and he justified that by his saying: "For indeed every people has an Eid and this is our Eid." I say: This justification is from his eloquence, peace and blessings be upon him, because on one hand he indicates by it his approval of Abu Bakr's denial of flutes (Mzamir) as a principle (Asl), and declares on the other hand his approval of the two girls' singing with the daff, indicating by that that it is an exception from the principle. As if he, peace and blessings be upon him, is saying to Abu Bakr: You were correct in your adherence to the principle, and you erred in your denial against the two girls, for it is a day of Eid. I had mentioned something like this in my introduction to Sheikh Nu'man Al-Alusi's book: Al-Ayat Al-Bayyinat fi 'Adam Sama' Al-Amwat. I asked in it p. 46-47: Where did Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, get this principle from? I said: The answer: It came from the teachings of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Hadiths are many in prohibiting singing and instruments of diversion. Then I mentioned some of their previous sources. Then I said: Were it not for Abu Bakr's knowledge of that and his being clear on the matter, he would not have advanced in the presence of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and in his house with such severe denial (1). However, it was hidden from him that this

So Abu Bakr's general denial remained accepted due to his, peace and blessings be upon him, approval of it, but singing in Eid was excepted from it, so it is permissible with the specifications mentioned in this Hadith. I had mentioned there in the referred introduction other examples indicating the importance of the Prophet's, peace and blessings be upon him, approval of a saying, and that it is one of the strong reasons for understanding the subject in which approval occurred correctly. Among that is the Hadith of the well (Qalib) of Badr and his calling, peace and blessings be upon him, to the slain polytheists in it: "O so-and-so son of so-and-so.." and the saying of Umar and others from the Companions: "What do you speak to bodies with no souls in them?" So he approved them on that but answered them by his saying: "You do not hear what I say more than them." Agreed upon. So I used this story as evidence there that the default regarding the dead is that they do not hear, based on two matters. What concerns me now is what relates to approval. So I said: p. 39-42: The other matter: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, approved Umar and others from the Companions on what was settled in their souls and belief that the dead do not hear. Some of them alluded to that and some mentioned it explicitly. But the two matters need clarification, so I say: As for the allusion, it is in the Companions' hastening when they heard his call, peace and blessings be upon him, to the dead of the well by their saying: "What do you speak to bodies with no souls in them?" For in another narration from Anas

text: similar to it with the wording: "They said" instead of: "Umar said". Were it not that they had previous knowledge of that which they received from him, peace and blessings be upon him, they would not have hastened to say that to him. Even if we assume they were hasty and denied without previous knowledge, the duty of notification (Tabligh) then required the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to clarify to them that this belief of theirs is wrong and has no basis in Sharia. We did not see in any of the narrations of the Hadith such clarification. The most he said to them was: "You do not hear what I say more than them." This - as you see - does not contain establishing a general rule for all dead contradicting their previous belief. Rather, it is information about the people of the well specifically. Moreover, that is not absolute as explained previously. Their hearing then is specific to that time and to what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to them only. It is a specific incident with no generality, so it does not indicate they hear always and forever and everything said to them, nor does it include others of the dead absolutely. As for the explicit (statement), it is in what Ahmad narrated 3/287 from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: [Authentic] So Umar heard his voice and said: "O Messenger of Allah, do you call them after three (days)? And do they hear? Allah Mighty and Majestic says: {Indeed, you will not make the dead hear}." He said: "By the One in Whose hand is my soul, you do not hear [what I say] more than them, but they cannot answer." Its chain is authentic on the condition of Muslim. Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, explicitly stated that the mentioned Verse is the reliance in that hastening, and that they understood from its generality the inclusion of the people of the well in it. Therefore, the matter was confusing to them, so they declared that to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to remove their confusion, and that was by his previous explanation.

text: From it, it becomes clear that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, approved the Companions - headed by Umar - on their understanding of the Verse in that general sense including the dead of the well and others, because he did not deny it on them nor say to them: You erred, for the Verse does not negate the hearing of the dead absolutely. Rather, he approved them on that but clarified to them what was hidden from them regarding the state of the well, and that they truly heard his speech, and that is a specific matter excepted from the Verse as a miracle for him, peace and blessings be upon him, as preceded. Then I said there: Be aware of this and know that it is from precise Fiqh to take care in tracking what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, approved of matters and using it as evidence, because his approval is truth as is known. Otherwise, without it, understanding might stray from correctness in many texts. We will not take you far; this is the witness before you. Many authors and others have become accustomed to using this Hadith - the Hadith of the well - as evidence that the dead hear, holding onto the apparent meaning of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "You do not hear what I say more than them," not paying attention to his, peace and blessings be upon him, approval of the Companions on their belief that the dead do not hear... Thus the Hadith returns - by paying attention to what we mentioned - as a proof that the dead do not hear, and that this is the default (Asl). So it is not permissible to depart from it except with a text, as is the case in every general text. And Allah is the Guardian of success. The researcher might find many examples of this type. Perhaps it is useful to mention here what is present in my mind now of that, and they are two examples... Then I mentioned them, and one of them is this (Hadith of) Aisha, so I said after it p. 46:

text: I said: So we find in this Hadith that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not deny Abu Bakr As-Siddiq's saying: "Flute of Satan," rather he approved him on that. His approval of him indicates that that is known (Ma'ruf) and not denied (Munkar). So where did Abu Bakr As-Siddiq get that from? The answer... etc. what was quoted previously p. 107-108. Then I said p. 47: Thus it became clear that he, peace and blessings be upon him, just as he approved Umar on his denunciation of the dead hearing, likewise approved Abu Bakr on his denunciation of the flute of Satan. And just as he introduced a specification to the first, likewise he introduced a specification to this saying of Abu Bakr which necessitated the permissibility of the mentioned singing on the day of Eid. Whoever neglected observing the approval we explained took from the Hadith permissibility in all days as pleases some contemporary writers and their predecessor in it Ibn Hazm... Then I said p. 48-49: As for the fact that he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not deny on the two girls - it is true, but that was on a day of Eid, so it does not include other than it. This is first. Second: When he, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered Abu Bakr not to deny on them by his saying: "Leave them," he followed that with his saying: "For indeed every people has an Eid..." This is a causative sentence indicating that the cause (Illah) of permissibility is 'Eid-ness' - if the expression is correct. It is known that the ruling revolves with the cause in existence and non-existence. So if this cause is negated by not being a day of Eid, singing is not permitted in it as is apparent. But Ibn Hazm perhaps does not hold the evidence of cause (Dalil al-Illah) as is known about him that he does not hold

text: the evidence of address (Dalil al-Khitab/Mafhum al-Mukhalafa). Scholars have refuted him, especially Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah in more than one place in Majmu' Al-Fatawa, so refer to the second volume of its index. The speech on the Hadith of Aisha regarding hearing singing has become long, and there is no harm in that, Allah the Exalted willing, for the witness from it is clear and important. It is that the student of knowledge's observation of the Prophet's, peace and blessings be upon him, approval of a matter opens for him a door of Fiqh and understanding he would not have reached without it. Such was the case in the Hadith of the well. The Conclusion: Ibn Hazm's error originated from his illusion that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, denied Abu Bakr's denial on the two girls absolutely, and not from his, peace and blessings be upon him, approval of the two girls. That is because this only indicates a permissibility restricted to a day of Eid as preceded, and to the daff not all instruments of diversion, and to young females as stated by scholars. Ibn Al-Jawzi said in Talbis Iblis 1/239: "The apparent regarding these two girls is young age because Aisha was young and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to send girls to her to play with her (1)." Therefore, I do not think Ibn Hazm would generalize the ruling were it not for that illusion. My thought is supported by the mentioned Hadith of sending (girls to play), for he adopted it in its specific indication and did not generalize it. He said in Al-Muhalla 10/75-76: "It is permissible for young girls specifically to play with images (dolls), and it is not lawful for others..." I say: This is the Fiqh required by combining texts, like the general with the specific

text: "If it were forbidden (Haram), the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would not have allowed Ibn Umar to hear it, nor would Ibn Umar have allowed Nafi' to hear it. But he, peace be upon him, disliked everything that is not of drawing closer to Allah, just as he disliked eating while reclining and... and... If that were forbidden, he, peace be upon him, would not have limited himself to blocking his ears from it without ordering it be stopped and forbidding it." So I say: May Allah forgive Ibn Hazm, for matters were hidden from him that are not befitting his knowledge to be hidden from him: First: The difference between 'Sama' (hearing) and 'Istima' (listening) was absent from him, so he interpreted the first as the second, which is an apparent error linguistically, Quranically, and Sunnah-wise. Therefore, Ibn Taymiyyah said following the Hadith of Aisha mentioned previously: "And there is not in the Hadith of the two girls that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, listened to that. Command and prohibition only relate to listening, not mere hearing, as in seeing; it only relates to the intention of looking, not what occurs unintentionally. Similarly in smelling perfume, the Muhrim is only forbidden from intending to smell, but if he smells what he did not intend, there is nothing on him. Likewise in experiencing prohibitions like the five senses of hearing, sight, smell, taste, and touch; command and prohibition in that only relate to what the servant has intention and action in. As for what happens without his choice, there is no command or prohibition in it." This is among what the Hadith of Ibn Umar was interpreted with... so he mentioned it. For some people say - assuming the authenticity of the Hadith (1) - why did he not order Ibn Umar to block his ears? It is answered that Ibn Umar was not listening but rather hearing, and there is no sin in this. The Prophet only diverted seeking

text: the more perfect and better, like one who passed on his way and heard people speaking with forbidden speech, so he blocked his ears so as not to hear it. This is better. Even if he did not block his ears, he would not bear sin by that, unless there is in his hearing a religious harm that is not repelled except by blocking. Second: That Ibn Hazm seems to imagine that the piping shepherd was in front of him, peace and blessings be upon him, so he could order and forbid him. There is nothing in the Hadith of that. Rather, perhaps there is in it what might indicate the opposite, which is that he was far away, his person not seen, but his voice heard. Therefore, the scholar Ibn Abdul-Hadi said after mentioning similar speech to Ibn Taymiyyah, its summary is: And the approval of the shepherd does not indicate its permissibility because it is a specific incident. Perhaps he heard him without seeing him, or far from him on a mountaintop or a place impossible to reach, or perhaps the shepherd was not religiously accountable (Mukallaf), so denial was not incumbent upon him (1). Third: That the prohibition of singing and instruments of diversion is not more severely prohibited than wine. And he knows that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, lived as long as Allah willed among his companions while they were drinking it before prohibition. So is it correct to say: That he, peace and blessings be upon him, approved them and did not forbid them? Likewise we say - assuming the indication of the Hadith for permissibility -: It is possible that it was before prohibition. With probability, deduction falls. Fourth and Last: And on the mentioned assumption, it is a specific permissibility for the shepherd's flute, which is a primitive, naive, silly instrument in terms of its arousing of souls and moving of natures and taking them out of the limit of moderation. So where is it compared to other instruments like the oud and qanun

text: and other instruments that diversified with the passage of time, especially in the present era, and some singers were afflicted with using them and the public with listening to them and being distracted by them? There is no doubt that the evidence in this Hadith - and on the mentioned assumption - is more specific than the claim, as the Fuqaha say. Otherwise, the truth is that there is no evidence in it at all. Rather, in it is evidence for the dislike of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, for the sound of the shepherd's flute. It is undoubtedly a legislative dislike, entering into the generality of His saying, Exalted is He: {There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern.} Therefore, Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, followed him and put his fingers in his ears despite the absence of intention (to listen) as we explained. So with the presence of intention, it is more severely disliked as is not hidden. Therefore Ibn Al-Jawzi, may Allah have mercy on him, said p. 247: "If this was their action regarding a sound that does not exceed moderation, how about the singing of the people of the time and their piping?!" I say: Then what is said about the people of our time and their music? Is there anyone who takes heed? This, and before concluding the speech on this chapter, it appeared to me to present the readers with a rare beneficial narration (Athar) which I did not see anyone who wrote on instruments of diversion address. A questioner might say: We have known from the preceding Hadiths, researches, and statements of scholars the prohibition of all musical instruments without exception, except the Daff (tambourine) in weddings and Eid. So, is there another occasion where the Daff is also permissible?

"This Hadith may seem problematic to some people because beating the Daff is a sin in other than weddings and Eid, and a sin cannot be vowed nor fulfilled. **7 - Chapter Seven: Regarding Singing Without an Instrument**

A sayer might say: Here we are, having known the ruling on singing with musical instruments and that it is forbidden except for the Daff in weddings and Eid. So what is the ruling on singing without an instrument?
In answer to this, I say: It is not correct to state absolutely that it is forbidden, because there is no evidence for this absolute statement. Just as it is not correct to state absolutely that it is permissible, as some Sufis and others among the people of desires, old and new, do. This is because singing is usually done with poetry, and poetry is not absolutely forbidden. How could it be, when the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) says: "Indeed, some poetry is wisdom." Narrated by Al-Bukhari, and it is referenced in *Al-Sahihah* (2851). Rather, he used to cite some of it occasionally, such as the poetry of Abdullah bin Rawahah (may Allah be pleased with him): "And he will bring you the news, the one whom you did not provision." This is referenced in *Al-Sahihah* (2057). See the comment on it in my new book: *Sahih Adab al-Mufrad* (p. 322). For that reason, upon him be blessings and peace, when asked about poetry, he said: [Authentic] "It is speech; its good is good, and its bad is bad." It is referenced in *Al-Sahihah* as well (447). Likewise, the lady...

He moves from dignity and tranquility to excessive speech, lying, loud laughter (Zahzahah), and cracking fingers. He tilts his head, shakes his shoulders, strikes the ground with his feet, knocks on the crown of his head with his hands, leaps the leaps of flies, spins the spinning of a donkey around the mill, claps with his hands the clapping of women, and lows out of ecstasy like the lowing of oxen. Sometimes he groans the groaning of the sad, and sometimes he screams the screams of the insane. The one expert in it among its people spoke the truth where he says:
'Do you remember a night when we gathered...
Upon good listening until the morning?
The cup of songs circulated among us...
So it intoxicated the souls without wine.'"

So you saw none among them but drunkards... with joy, while joy there is sober.

Some of the gnostics said: Listening (to music/singing) bequeaths hypocrisy in some people, stubbornness in some, lying in some, immorality in some, and frivolity in some. Until he said: So singing corrupts the heart, and if the heart is corrupted, hypocrisy stirs within it.

And with Allah is success.

I say: After the wisdom behind the prohibition of singing has become clear from the preceding narrations—which is that it distracts from the obedience of Allah and His remembrance, and this is witnessed—then those who are distracted by it, whether making others listen or listening themselves, each has their share of the dispraise mentioned in the noble Verse: {And of the people is he who buys the amusement of speech to mislead [others] from the way of Allah...} [Luqman: 6]. This is according to the extent of distraction, be it little or much. You have known that "buying" means exchanging and choosing. With an important note, which is that the "Lam" in His saying, Exalted is He: {Li-yudilla} (to mislead) is the Lam of consequence (Al-Aqibah) as in Al-Wahidi's Tafsir, meaning: so that his affair ends up in misguidance, as Ibn Al-Jawzi said in Al-Zad 6/317. It is not for reasoning (purpose) as some say, although it has validity regarding the disbelievers who take the verses of Allah in ridicule. Therefore, Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said (1/240):

And when the Qur'an is recited to him, he turns away arrogantly as if he did not hear it, as if there is deafness in his ears—which is heaviness and deafness—and if he knows anything of it, he mocks it. The total of this does not occur except from the people of greatest disbelief. However, if some of it occurs to the singers and their listeners, they have a portion and a share of this dispraise.
This is clarified by the fact that you do not find anyone who cares for singing and listening to musical instruments except that there is misguidance in him regarding the path of guidance, in knowledge and action, and there is a turning away from listening to the Qur'an towards listening to singing. Such that if listening to singing and listening to the Qur'an are presented to him, he turns from this to that, and listening to the Qur'an becomes heavy upon him. Perhaps the situation leads him to silence the reciter and deem his reading too long, while asking the singer to do more and deeming his turn too short. The least that is in this is that he receives a plentiful share of this dispraise, even if he does not acquire all of it.
This speech is addressed to those who have some life in their hearts that they can feel. As for the one whose heart has died and whose tribulation has become great, the path of advice is blocked for him. {And whoever Allah wants to put in trial, you will never possess for him [the power to do] anything against Allah. Those are the ones for whom Allah does not intend to purify their hearts. For them in this world is disgrace, and for them in the Hereafter is a great punishment.} [Al-Ma'idah: 41].

I say: From those Salafi narrations and Ibn al-Qayyim's commentary on them with his wonderful and beneficial words, the error of Ibn Hazm becomes clearly apparent to you in his saying, after citing most of them:

As for the first: It is a word of truth by which falsehood is intended, because it implies that the narrations (Athar) contradict what came from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in interpreting the verse. "The gnostic is the one who looks at causes towards their ends and results, and contemplates their objectives

The prohibitions of the Sharia are of two types: A type prohibited because of the corruption within it, and a type prohibited because it is a means to what contains corruption.
Whoever looks at the form of this prohibition without looking at what it is a means to, will find the reason for its prohibition problematic and will say: What corruption is there in looking at a beautiful image created by Allah the Exalted and made as a sign pointing to Him? Had He permitted the means to corruptions while prohibiting them (the corruptions), it would be a contradiction He is exalted above. Sufi Singing and Islamic Anasheed (Nasheeds).
After we have clarified the forbidden singing in its two parts: with instruments and without them, relying in that on the Book of Allah, the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, the Salafi narrations, and the sayings of the Imams, it is time for us to speak about Sufi singing and what is known today as "Islamic or Religious Anasheed."
So I say, and I seek Allah's help:
There is no doubt that just as it is not permissible for us to worship anyone but Allah in realization of the testimony that "There is no deity worthy of worship except Allah," likewise it is not permissible for us to worship Allah or draw near to Him except through what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, brought, in realization of the testimony that "Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah." If the believer realizes this, he becomes loving of Allah, following His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him. And whoever Allah loves, Allah is with him and is his Helper.
I had mentioned in the introduction of my commentary on the treatise of Al-Izz bin Abd al-Salam, may Allah have mercy on him, "Bidayat al-Sul fi Tafdil al-Rasul" (The Beginning of the Quest regarding the Preference of the Messenger), after two known hadiths regarding the love of Allah and the Messenger and that whoever has that finds the sweetness of faith, the following text:
"Know, O Muslim brother, that no one can ascend to this station of love for Allah and His Messenger except by singling out Allah the Exalted in His worship excluding others, and by singling out the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in following excluding other servants of Allah, due to His saying, Exalted is He: 'He who obeys the Messenger has obeyed Allah,' and His saying: {Say, "If you should love Allah, then follow me, [so] Allah will love you"}, and his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, if Moses were alive, he would have no choice but to follow me.'" There is no doubt that whoever Allah loves, Allah is with him in everything, as in the authentic Qudsi Hadith: "And My servant does not draw near to Me with anything more beloved to Me than what I have obligated upon him. If I love him, I become his hearing with which he hears, his sight with which he sees, his hand with which he strikes, and his foot with which he walks. It has become clear from Chapter Seven what is permissible to sing of poetry and what is not permissible. Just as it became clear from what preceded it the prohibition of all instruments of diversion except the daff in Eid and Wedding for women. And from this last chapter, that it is not permissible to draw near to Allah except through what Allah legislated. So how can it be permissible to draw near to Him with what He prohibited? And that for this reason, scholars prohibited Sufi singing and their denial intensified against those who declared it lawful.
If the reader recalls these strong principles in his mind, it becomes clear to him with all clarity that there is no difference in terms of ruling between Sufi singing and Religious Anasheed. Rather, there might be in this (Anasheed) another calamity, which is that they might be composed to the melodies of immoral songs and performed according to musical rules, Eastern or Western, which delight the listeners, make them dance, and take them out of their composure. So the intent becomes the melody and the delight (Tarab), not the Nasheed itself. This is a new violation, which is imitation of the disbelievers and the immoral.
Another violation might result from that, which is imitating them in their turning away from the Qur'an and abandoning it. So they enter into the generality of the Prophet's complaint, peace and blessings be upon him, about his people as in the saying of the Exalted: {And the Messenger has said, "O my Lord, indeed my people have taken this Qur'an as [a thing] abandoned.".}
I remember well that when I was in Damascus - two years before my emigration to here, Amman - some Muslim youth began to sing some Anasheed with sound meaning, intending by that to counter Sufi singing with the likes of the poems of Al-Busiri and others. They recorded that on a tape. It did not take long until they coupled with it beating on the daff. Then they used it at first in wedding parties on the basis that the daff is permissible in them. That became their solace and their constant habit. That is only from the dominance of desire and ignorance of Satan's plots. So he diverted them from caring for the Qur'an and hearing it, let alone studying it, and it became abandoned by them as came in the noble Verse.
Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in its Tafsir 3/317: "The Exalted says informing about His Messenger and Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: {O my Lord, indeed my people have taken this Qur'an as [a thing] abandoned.} That is because the polytheists did not listen to the Qur'an nor pay attention to it, as the Exalted said: {And those who disbelieved said, "Do not listen to this Qur'an and speak noisily during [the recitation of] it..."} the Verse. So when the Qur'an was recited to them, they would increase clamor and speech in other things so they would not hear it. This is from abandoning it. Leaving faith in it and leaving believing in it is from abandoning it. Leaving pondering it and understanding it is from abandoning it. Leaving acting upon it and complying with its commands and avoiding its prohibitions is from abandoning it. Turning away from it to other things like poetry, speech, singing, amusement, talk, or a method taken from other than it is from abandoning it."
So we ask Allah, the Generous, the Bestower, the Able to do what He wills, to purify us from what angers Him and use us in what pleases Him of memorizing His Book, understanding it, and undertaking its requirements throughout the night and ends of the day in the manner He loves and is pleased with. Indeed, He is Generous, Bestower.
This is the last of what Allah, Blessed and Exalted, facilitated to draft of this treatise. May Allah benefit His servants with it.
